Presenting Problem / Chief Complaint: The patient expresses feelings of contentment but acknowledges some dissatisfaction with aspects of life, particularly related to the loss of a family member and mild cognitive impairment
Trauma History: The patient recently lost his uncle, who raised him, which has caused significant emotional distress. He reflects on the difficulty of making the decision to let his uncle pass away while on life support
History of Present Illness (HPI): The patient reports feeling depressed after the loss of his uncle but is gradually improving. He also mentions experiencing mild cognitive impairment and forgetfulness, which he attributes to stress and grief
Medical and Psychiatric History: The patient has a history of depression and anxiety, diagnosed in 2001. He takes medication for these conditions
Psychosocial History: The patient identifies as a Californian originally from Brooklyn. He works as a welder and has a supportive relationship with his wife, who he describes as his best friend. He enjoys spending time with her and values their companionship
Physiological Observations: The patient reports sleeping about four to five hours a night and does not feel tired despite this. He acknowledges being heavier than he would like and is finding it challenging to maintain a healthy lifestyle
Diagnostic Impressions: The patient has been diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment, which may be exacerbated by his recent grief and depression
Progress Evaluation: The patient is gradually improving emotionally but is still coping with the effects of his uncle's death and his cognitive challenges
Medications: The patient is currently taking medication for depression and anxiety, which he finds effective
Next Steps: The patient will return for a follow-up with a neurologist in a year to reassess his cognitive condition
